messageBody:
Sorry if this is a question that has already been discussed (it
probably has because its so obvious, but I could not find anything
about it). I want to write test cases that reference interfaces only
as I want to publish them as part of a spec Â– they are to define the
semantics of classes. For instance, I want to write a test case for
lists like this:

class TestList extends TestCase {
List testedObject = null;
public void test1() {
testedObject.clear();
testedObject.add("object");
assertTrue(1==testedObject.size());
}
}

How can I use TestList without subclassing it and explicitly
initialising testedObject in setUp() (or another method using the
JUnit4 annotation). In other words, is there an elegant dependency
injection mechanism that can be used here? I could use a constructor
to set the implementation class instance, but I understand that JUnit
test runners use reflection to instantiate test cases. A solution
would be a test runner that uses an map associating test case classes
with implementation classes (to be tested), and uses this info to
instantiate the test cases. Is there anything like this out there?
Thanks in advance for any idea!

Jens
